abstract_sentences.1: In this paper, we present the gated selfmatching networks for reading comprehension style question answering, which aims to answer questions from a given passage.
abstract_sentences.2: We first match the question and passage with gated attention-based recurrent networks to obtain the question-aware passage representation.
abstract_sentences.3: Then we propose a self-matching attention mechanism to refine the representation by matching the passage against itself, which effectively encodes information from the whole passage.
abstract_sentences.4: We finally employ the pointer networks to locate the positions of answers from the passages.
abstract_sentences.5: We conduct extensive experiments on the SQuAD dataset.
abstract_sentences.6: The single model achieves 71.3% on the evaluation metrics of exact match on the hidden test set, while the ensemble model further boosts the results to 75.9%.
abstract_sentences.7: At the time of submission of the paper, our model holds the first place on the SQuAD leaderboard for both single and ensemble model.

body_sentences.2: We specifically focus on the Stanford Question Answering Dataset (SQuAD) (Rajpurkar et al., 2016), a largescale dataset for reading comprehension and question answering which is manually created through crowdsourcing.

body_sentences.7: Rapid progress has been made since the release of the SQuAD dataset.
body_sentences.8: Wang and Jiang (2016b) build question-aware passage representation with match-LSTM (Wang and Jiang, 2016a), and predict answer boundaries in the passage with pointer networks (Vinyals et al., 2015).
body_sentences.10: (2016) introduce bi-directional attention flow networks to model question-passage pairs at multiple levels of granularity.
body_sentences.12: (2016) propose dynamic co-attention networks which attend the question and passage simultaneously and iteratively refine answer predictions.
body_sentences.15: (2016) predict answers by ranking continuous text spans within passages.
body_sentences.16: Inspired by Wang and Jiang (2016b), we introduce a gated self-matching network, illustrated in Figure 1, an end-to-end neural network model for reading comprehension and question answering.
body_sentences.17: Our model consists of four parts: 1) the recurrent network encoder to build representation for questions and passages separately, 2) the gated matching layer to match the question and passage, 3) the self-matching layer to aggregate information from the whole passage, and 4) the pointernetwork based answer boundary prediction layer.
body_sentences.18: The key contributions of this work are three-fold.
body_sentences.19: First, we propose a gated attention-based recurrent network, which adds an additional gate to the attention-based recurrent networks (Bahdanau et al., 2014; Rocktäschel et al., 2015; Wang and Jiang, 2016a), to account for the fact that words in the passage are of different importance to answer a particular question for reading comprehension and question answering.
body_sentences.20:
In Wang and Jiang (2016a), words in a passage with their corresponding attention-weighted question context are en-

coded together to produce question-aware passage representation.
body_sentences.21: By introducing a gating mechanism, our gated attention-based recurrent network assigns different levels of importance to passage parts depending on their relevance to the question, masking out irrelevant passage parts and emphasizing the important ones.
body_sentences.22: Second, we introduce a self-matching mechanism, which can effectively aggregate evidence from the whole passage to infer the answer.
body_sentences.23: Through a gated matching layer, the resulting question-aware passage representation effectively encodes question information for each passage word.
body_sentences.24: However, recurrent networks can only memorize limited passage context in practice despite its theoretical capability.
body_sentences.25: One answer candidate is often unaware of the clues in other parts of the passage.
body_sentences.26: To address this problem, we propose a self-matching layer to dynamically refine passage representation with information from the whole passage.
body_sentences.27: Based on question-aware passage representation, we employ gated attention-based recurrent networks on passage against passage itself, aggregating evidence relevant to the current passage word from every word in the passage.
body_sentences.28: A gated attention-based recurrent network layer and self-matching layer dynamically enrich each passage representation with information aggregated from both question and passage, enabling subsequent network to better predict answers.
body_sentences.29: Lastly, the proposed method yields state-of-theart results against strong baselines.
body_sentences.30: Our single model achieves 71.3% exact match accuracy on the hidden SQuAD test set, while the ensemble model further boosts the result to 75.9%.
body_sentences.31: At the time1 of submission of this paper, our model holds the first place on the SQuAD leader board.
body_sentences.32: 2 Task Description  For reading comprehension style question answering, a passage P and question Q are given, our task is to predict an answer A to question Q based on information found in P. The SQuAD dataset further constrains answer A to be a continuous subspan of passage P. Answer A often includes nonentities and can be much longer phrases.
body_sentences.33: This setup challenges us to understand and reason about both the question and passage in order to infer the answer.

body_sentences.36: First, the question and passage are processed by a bi-directional recurrent network (Mikolov et al., 2010) separately.
body_sentences.37: We then match the question and passage with gated attention-based recurrent networks, obtaining question-aware representation for the passage.
body_sentences.38: On top of that, we apply self-matching attention to aggregate evidence from the whole passage and refine the passage representation, which is then fed into the output layer to predict the boundary of the answer span.

body_sentences.60: 3.3 Self-Matching Attention  Through gated attention-based recurrent networks, question-aware passage representation {vPt }nt=1 is generated to pinpoint important parts in the passage.
body_sentences.61: One problem with such representation is that it has very limited knowledge of context.

body_sentences.63: Moreover, there exists some sort of lexical or syntactic divergence between the question and passage in the majority of SQuAD dataset (Rajpurkar et al., 2016).
body_sentences.64: Passage context is necessary to infer the answer.
body_sentences.65: To address this problem, we propose directly matching the question-aware passage representation against itself.

body_sentences.77: 4 Experiment    4.1 Implementation Details  We specially focus on the SQuAD dataset to train and evaluate our model, which has garnered a huge attention over the past few months.
body_sentences.78: SQuAD is composed of 100,000+ questions posed by crowd workers on 536 Wikipedia articles.
body_sentences.79: The dataset is randomly partitioned into a training set (80%), a development set (10%), and a test set (10%).
body_sentences.80: The answer to every question is a segment of the corresponding passage.
body_sentences.81: We use the tokenizer from Stanford CoreNLP (Manning et al., 2014) to preprocess each passage and question.
body_sentences.82: The Gated Recurrent Unit (Cho et al., 2014) variant of LSTM is used throughout our model.
body_sentences.83: For word embedding, we use pretrained case-sensitive GloVe embeddings2 (Pennington et al., 2014) for both questions and passages, and it is fixed during training; We use zero vectors to represent all out-of-vocab words.
body_sentences.84: We utilize 1 layer of bi-directional GRU to compute character-level embeddings and 3 layers of bi-directional GRU to encode questions and passages, the gated attention-based recurrent network for question and passage matching is also encoded bidirectionally in our experiment.
body_sentences.85: The hidden vector length is set to 75 for all layers.
body_sentences.86: The hidden size used to compute attention scores is also 75.
body_sentences.87: We also apply dropout (Srivastava et al., 2014) between layers with a dropout rate of 0.2.
body_sentences.88: The model is optimized with AdaDelta (Zeiler, 2012) with an initial learning rate of 1.
body_sentences.89: The ρ and used in AdaDelta are 0.95 and 1e−6 respectively.
body_sentences.91: 4.2 Main Results  Two metrics are utilized to evaluate model performance: Exact Match (EM) and F1 score.
body_sentences.92: EM measures the percentage of the prediction that matches one of the ground truth answers exactly.
body_sentences.93: F1 measures the overlap between the prediction and ground truth answers which takes the maximum F1 over all of the ground truth answers.
body_sentences.94: The scores on dev set are evaluated by the official script3.
body_sentences.95: Since the test set is hidden, we are required to submit the model to Stanford NLP group to obtain the test scores.

body_sentences.124: 6 Related Work  Reading Comprehension and Question Answering Dataset Benchmark datasets play an important role in recent progress in reading comprehension and question answering research.
body_sentences.125:
Exist-
ing datasets can be classified into two categories according to whether they are manually labeled.
body_sentences.126: Those that are labeled by humans are always in high quality (Richardson et al., 2013; Berant et al., 2014; Yang et al., 2015), but are too small for training modern data-intensive models.
body_sentences.127: Those that are automatically generated from natural occurring data can be very large (Hill et al., 2016; Hermann et al., 2015), which allow the training of more expressive models.
body_sentences.128: However, they are in cloze style, in which the goal is to predict the missing word (often a named entity) in a passage.
body_sentences.130: (2016) have shown that the CNN / Daily News dataset (Hermann et al., 2015) requires less reasoning than previously thought, and conclude that performance is almost saturated.
body_sentences.131: Different from above datasets, the SQuAD provides a large and high-quality dataset.
body_sentences.132: The answers in SQuAD often include non-entities and can be much longer phrase, which is more challenging than cloze-style datasets.
body_sentences.134: (2016) show that the dataset retains a diverse set of answers and requires different forms of logical reasoning, including multi-sentence reasoning.
body_sentences.135: MS MARCO (Nguyen et al., 2016) is also a large-scale dataset.

The questions in the dataset
are real anonymized queries issued through Bing or Cortana and the passages are related web pages.
body_sentences.137: For each question in the dataset, several related passages are provided.
body_sentences.138: However, the answers are human generated, which is different from SQuAD where answers must be a span of the passage.

self-matching attention in our model.
body_sentences.171: It dynamically refines the passage representation by looking over the whole passage and aggregating evidence relevant to the current passage word and question, allowing our model make full use of passage information.
body_sentences.172: Weightedly attending to word context has been proposed in several works.
body_sentences.174: (2015) propose considering window-based contextual words differently depending on the word and its relative position.
body_sentences.176: (2016) propose a novel LSTM network to encode words in a sentence which considers the relation between the current token being processed and its past tokens in the memory.
body_sentences.178: (2016) apply this method to encode words in a sentence according to word form and its distance.
body_sentences.179: Since passage information relevant to question is more helpful to infer the answer in reading comprehension, we apply self-matching based on question-aware representation and gated attention-based recurrent networks.
body_sentences.180: It helps our model mainly focus on question-relevant evidence in the passage and dynamically look over the whole passage to aggregate evidence.
body_sentences.181: Another key component of our model is the attention-based recurrent network, which has demonstrated success in a wide range of tasks.
body_sentences.183: (2014) first propose attentionbased recurrent networks to infer word-level alignment when generating the target word.
body_sentences.185: (2015) introduce word-level attention into reading comprehension to model the interaction between questions and passages.
body_sentences.187: (2015) and Wang and Jiang (2016a) propose determining entailment via word-by-word matching.
body_sentences.188: The gated attention-based recurrent network is a variant of attention-based recurrent network with an additional gate to model the fact that passage parts are of different importance to the particular question for reading comprehension and question answering.
body_sentences.189: 7 Conclusion  In this paper, we present gated self-matching networks for reading comprehension and question answering.
body_sentences.190: We introduce the gated attentionbased recurrent networks and self-matching attention mechanism to obtain representation for the question and passage, and then use the pointernetworks to locate answer boundaries.
body_sentences.191:
Our model achieves state-of-the-art results on the SQuAD
dataset, outperforming several strong competing systems.
body_sentences.192: As for future work, we are applying the gated self-matching networks to other reading comprehension and question answering datasets, such as the MS MARCO dataset (Nguyen et al., 2016).
